messageBody:
Ilja Preuss wrote:
>> in Java
>> everything that's public is published, whether you want it to be or
>> not.
>
> That's not true. Even in Sun's libraries, there are public classes and
> methods in com.sun packages, which per convention aren't *published*. If you
> use them, you do so at your own peril.


And guess what? People use them, even though they aren't supposed to.
Even major projects by really good developers when should know better
use them. For instance, until the very latest version Xerces directly
accessed sun.io classes. Hell, I even wrote a book whose primary focus
was on documenting, explaining, and teaching people to use the sun classes!

If gentlemen's agreements were sufficient to enforce constraints on
usage, we never would have had to invent access protection in the first
place. public == published in Java. I certainly wish it were otherwise,
but sadly that's not the case.
